repnme.cdata!:
Cote d'Ivoire - Energy Sector
            Adjustment Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Energy Sector
            Adjustment Program for Cote d'Ivoire was satisfactory.
            The project achieved most of its objectives, institutional
            development was partially achieved, sustainability is
            likely, and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower
            was satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, closer attention to EECI's parlous
            condition during the design of the loan would probably have
            improved the impact of the operation. Second, future Bank
            operations should address the issue of funds being used for
            non-project related activities. Third, regulatory issues
            should have been foreseen at the time the loan was designed
            and should be included in future Bank or IDA operations in
            the sector. Fourth, the problems relating to the
            introduction of a market-linked system for setting petroleum
            product price ceilings and, to a certain degree, the lack of
            progress in rationalizing the product storage and
            distribution, point to the weakening effect that waivers may
            have on the substance of the operation. Finally, initial
            conditions for tranche release should probably have been
            maintained, despite any delays that might have ensued.

repnme.cdata!:
Cote d'Ivoire - Energy Sector
            Adjustment Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The Energy Sector Adjustment Loan
            willsupport the Government's comprehensive program of
            reforms in the energy sector, within the framework of its
            ongoing structural adjustment program. The main program
            objectives are : 1) accelerating development of indigenous
            energy resources, where possible with increased
            participation of the private sector, 2) improving investment
            planning, 3) increasing operational efficiency and
            strengthening financial management of energy enterprises, 4)
            improved resource allocation and 5) institutional
            streamlining.  To this end, the program contains the
            following elements: new contractual framework for
            hydrocarbon exploration and development, review of the
            energy project portfolio to define an optimum investment
            program, internal reorganization and financial restructuring
            of energy parastatals, selective energy price reductions and
            clarification of Government responsibilities with respect to
            policy making and supervision through legislation and
            performance contracts.
